title: The Map as Intent: Variations on the Theme of John Snow
author: Tom Koch
description: "Mapping is not value-free, dangers occur when professional cartographers and geographers attempt to map data from fields in which they are ignorant. "

title: Megan Jaegerman's brilliant news graphics
author: Edward Tufte

title: Whom the Gods Would Destroy, They First Give Real-time Analytics
author: Dan McKinley
description: This essay's theme encompasses the frustration of engineers, the wild imaginations of product managers, and the proper use of statistics.

title: The Untold Story Behind Kickstarter Stats
author: Jeanne Pi

title: Public Info Doesn't Always Want to Be Free
author: Matt Waite
description: Is it possible to run a mugshot-aggregating website and still follow journalistic ethics?

title: Using Big Data to Ask Big Questions
author: Chase Davis

title: Rap Stats: Breaking Down The Words in Rap Lyrics Over Time
author: ATodd & Rap Genius Engineering Team
description: "Rap’s history has been traced many ways -- through books, documentaries, official compilations, DJ mixes, university archives, even parties. But until now you haven’t been able to look at the development of the genre through its building blocks: the actual words used by emcees."

title: Book of Bad Arguments
author: Ali Almossawi

title: Nate Silver on Finding a Mentor, Teaching Yourself Statistics, and Not Settling in Your Career
author: Walter Frick
description: "That intellectual curiosity. That bullshit detector for lack of a better term, where you see a data set and you have at least a first approach on how much signal there is there...That stuff is kind of hard to teach through book learning. So it’s by experience. I would be an advocate if you’re going to have an education, then have it be a pretty diverse education so you’re flexing lots of different muscles...You can learn the technical skills later on"

title: How traffic actually works
author: Jason Liszka

title: Useful Junk? The Effects of Visual Embellishment on Comprehension and Memorability of Charts
author: The Interaction Lab at the University of Saskatchewan
description: Is the Tufte-school of aesthetic too boring for our Jerry-Bruckheimer-corrupted brains?

title: 8 Red Flags about the "Useful chartjunk" paper
description: A rebuttal to the University of Saskatchewan paper on whether "chartjunk" is more effective in conveying data.

title:
Pharmaceutical Company Payments to Physicians
Early Experiences With Disclosure Laws in Vermont and Minnesota
author: Joseph S. Ross, Josh E. Lackner, et al.
description: This landmark study that studied whether financial disclosure laws were actually being followed was the result of old-fashioned data collection: travelling to Minnesota and manually copying documents, before analyzing them in Access.

title: SQL: The Prequel (Excel vs. Databases)
author: Noah Veltman

title: Using Metadata to Find Paul Revere
author: Kieran Healy

title: WTF Visualizations
description: WTF indeed

title: How to be a data journalist
author: Paul Bradshaw

title: Computational Journalism
author: Sarah Cohen, James T. Hamilton, Fred Turner
description: The modern computing age may have irreperably damaged the business of journalism, but it may also streghten the act of journalism.

title: How We Did It: Waterloo crime map
author: Chris Essig
description: How to turn a PDF into a Leaflet-powered crime map.

title: How We Measured America’s Most Hospitable Cities
author: Andrey Fradkin, Riley Newman, Rebecca Rosenfelt

title: Everything you need to know about Machine Learning in 30 minutes or less
author: Hilary Mason
description: A brief overview geared toward engineers with no prior knowledge of machine learning.

title: Refining the Problem — More work with NYPL's open data, Part Two
author: Trevor Muñoz
description: Mmmm...munging

title: The Hot Spotters: Can we lower medical costs by giving the neediest patients better care?
author: Atul Gawande
description: A health-care themed example of how data analysis can discover counterintuitive solutions.

title: How The Rainbow Color Map Misleads
author: Robert Kosara
description: The importance of limiting colors in a visualization is one of the most un-obvious principles to grasp. And yet, once it's explained to you, you'll immediately look down on everyone else who failing to see the tackiness.

title: Why Most Published Research Findings Are False
author: John P. A. Ioannidis
description: One of the classics of scientific papers, influential and controversial to this day.

title: Red Versus Blue in a New Light
author: Andrew Gelman and Avi Feller
description: "What’s actually going on is that the division between red and blue America is mostly about a split among richer voters."

title: Rich state, poor state, red state, blue state: What’s the matter with Connecticut?
author: Andrew Gelman, Boris Shor, Joseph Bafumi, David Park

title: 7 command-line tools for data science
author: Jeroen Janssens
description: There's no shortage of ways to make data just a little bit easier to work with, and usually the effort is worth it.

title: A Taxonomy of Data Science
author: Hilary Mason and Chris Wiggins
description: Here's a way to look at data science as five distinct steps. Also, it's the first I've heard of the awesome acronym, OSEMN.

title: Explorations in Unix
author: Seth Brown
description: Quick, light-weight ways to reshape and visualize data from the command-line.

title: Which Polls Fared Best (and Worst) in the 2012 Presidential Race
author: Nate Silver
description: After a triumphant night of presidential election predictions, Nate Silver rubs it in by examining how the vairous pollsters did in their predictions.

title: Forecasting: principles and practice
author: Rob J. Hyndman and George Athanasopoulos
description: "This text­book is intended to pro­vide a com­pre­hen­sive intro­duc­tion to fore­cast­ing meth­ods and present enough infor­ma­tion about each method for read­ers to use them sen­si­bly. We don’t attempt to give a thor­ough dis­cus­sion of the the­o­ret­i­cal details behind each method, although the ref­er­ences at the end of each chap­ter will fill in many of those details."

title: A Visual Explanation of SQL Joins
author: Jeff Atwood
description: SQL joins illustrated with Venn diagrams

title: Model Analysis
author: Erik Hinton
description: The final product of this fashion interactive is of course a visualization. But Hinton's writeup is more about the analysis used to "fingerprint" each fashion pohoto.

title: Sweeping FOIAs, document-mining reveal problems with Norway kindergartens
author: John Bones
description: When it comes to large data-projects involving messy data, don't always get hung up on the technology to use. Coming up with an efficient way to divide and distribute the data collection and cleaning, even within your own newsroom, can often do the job

title: Megan Jaegerman's brilliant news graphics
author: Edward Tufte
description:
"Megan Jaegerman produced some of the best news graphics ever while working 
at The New York Times," according to Edward Tufte. Here's a gallery he put together of Jaegerman's work."

title: The Unprecedented is Overrated
author: Stephen Few
description: "Most of what we can do to make the world a better place involves, not doing the unprecedented, but doing what matters and what works, whether unprecedented or not. This might not be as exciting as the unprecedented, but it’s desperately needed."

title: Bullet Chart Design Specification
author: Stephen Few
description: An elegant and compact way to encode a metric with comparative data.

title: Scraping for Journalists
author: Paul Bradshaw
description: If you've ever tried to scrape a non-trivial website, you'll understand why this book is 80,000+ words long.

title: The Visual Display of Quantitative Information
author: Edward Tufte
description: This book was revolutionary when Tufte published it in 1982 and it remains just as relevant in our current state of PowerPoint and tacky CSS transitions.

title: Homicide: A Year on the Killing Streets
author: David Simon
description: OK, this is not a traditional data journalism book, though it's one of the best true crime and/or journalism books ever written. Simon does keep and review a tally of the bodies and where they marticulate in the Balitmore justice system throughout the year. Also, there's a memorable passage about the "murder board", a simple visualization that has unintended consequences on the efficency of the homicide squad.

title: Making charts (for curious readers)
author: Paul Krugman
description: After you laugh, remember: he's a Nobel Prize winner.

title: Interestingly: the sentence adverbs of PubMed Central
author: Neil Saunders
description: Saunders's blog is fascinating to me, as he describes his struggles (and triumphs) as a hobbyist programmer in a field - bioinformatics - that you'd think would embrace his type of coding skills. Here, he shows the code needed to analyze the writing tics found in 47 gigabytes of PubMed abstracts.

title: The vast majority of statistical analysis is not performed by statisticians
author: Jeff Leek

title: The Mathematics Of Beauty
author: Christian Rudder
description: This is both an interesting read about sex and relationships as well as something that should pique your interest about how online services measure your behavior.

title: Probabilities in the Game of Monopoly
author: Truman Collins

title: How to Write a Spelling Corrector
author: Peter Norvig
description: Because even his elite engineering and mathematics friends didn't understand how easy it is to make a spell-checker, Norvig explains the theory and shows the less-than-a-page-worth of code needed to achieve 80 to 90% accuracy.

title: If You Liked This, You’re Sure to Love That
author: Clive Thompson
description: "Merely knowing who people are, paradoxically, isn’t very predictive of their movie tastes."

title: How Gannett Wisconsin Media gathered salary data from cities, counties and state agencies
author: Sarah Harkins

title: Simulation Study of a Laundry Room
author: Iain Dunning
description: Simulations don't yet have much place in journalism, but I like this analysis of laundry room behavior because it acknowledges the limitation of analysis and the impact of assumptions, as well as intuitively walking through the design of the simulation (with Julia code snippets). Also, it tackles a question near to all of us.

title: Evil Analytics: How What You Measure Becomes Your Master
author: Ryan Holiday

title: White House Safety Datapalooza data journalism talk
author: Chrys Wu

title: The NYT's Amanda Cox on Winning the Internet
author: Erin Kissane
description: A visualization of what makes great visualizations at the New York Times

title: The One-Query Story
author: Kate Martin, Grant Smith, Megan Luther
description: A brilliant walkthrough of benign data sets and the code that could potentially launch  investigative projects.

title: Disputes over crime maps highlight challenge of outsourcing public data
author: Adam Hochberg

title: Oscar Predictions, Election Style
author: Nate Silver
description: The master of presidential predictions explains why he's not so great at predicting Oscar winners.

title: The Gettysburg Powerpoint Presentation
author: Peter Norvig
description: History's most memorable 3D-column chart.

title: Nightingale's Rose
author: Henry Woodbury
description: A modern critique of Florence Nightingale's, "Diagram of the Causes of Mortality"

title: chartsnthings
author: Kevin Quealy
description: A (personal) blog of data sketches from the New York Times Graphics Department. Maintained by @KevinQ.

title: How the Sun Sentinel reported its Pulitzer Prize winning coverage of off-duty cops
author: Sally Kestin and John Maines
description: This 2013 Pulitzer Public Service winning story epitomizes the best of watchdog journalism, as its expose of a deadly public injustice sparked swift reform. But it deserves an award for its ingenious do-it-yourself way of collecting the kind of data that, in theory, was non-existent.

title: Counting the Jay-Z subway crowd
author: John Keefe
description: Using the MTA turnstile data to see what kind of crowds Jay-Z drew at Jay-Z's inaugural concert with Barclays Center.

title: Mapping Dollars in a District
author: John Keefe
description: WNYC's political team wanted to know: how much money was being raised by candidates for a state legislative district from within the district itself? John Keefe walks through his use of Fusion Tables and additional database techniques for the analysis and visualization.

title: Free, Live Election data: Now's your chance to play
author: John Keefe
description: How to use Google-provided election data to build a Fusion Table-powered map.

title: Making the NYC Evacuation Map
author: John Keefe
description: One day John Keefe was just browsing the official NYC data site and tucked away some code that involved the city's flood zones. When Hurricane Irene stuck, NYC.gov was flooded (with web traffic) and WNYC became an invaluable resource.

title: Mapping Campaign Contributions on the Fly
author: John Keefe
description: With Fusion Tables and a little Ruby magic, John Keefe describes how he mapped contributions to presumptive NYC mayoral candidates by zip code by lunchtime.

title: We Have Met the Enemy and He Is PowerPoint
author: Elisabeth Bumiller
description: “When we understand that slide, we’ll have won the war.”

title: The Data Driven Congressional Reporter
author: Derek Willis
description: Why aren't more Congressional reporters taking advantage of the copious generated by our legislators?

title: On Legislative Data Transparency
author: Derek Willis
description: This says everything you need to know about the complexity and annoyance of real-life data: "For example, in the Senate it is possible for the Majority Leader and Minority Leader to alter the rules of math when it comes to how many senators constitute a three-fifths majority."

title: The NYPD's crash data has a booboo. Here's a band-aid.
author: John Krauss
description: Citizen data journalism at its best, from John Krauss: "I already knew that they were finally releasing -- after the Council forced them to -- crash data as idiotically obfuscated PDFs, but reading that they justified this out of concern for "the integrity of the data," was so galling that it goaded me into action. I would make the data accessible as friendly, parseable CSVs."

title: The Data Journalism Handbook
author: The European Journalism Center and the Open Knowledge Foundation
description: An international collaboration of the best of data journalism worldwide.

title: When Maps Shouldn’t Be Maps
author: Matthew Ericson
description: Computers have made mapping almost too easy, to the point where we overlook clearer, more efficient ways to display data that isn't particularly geospatially interesting.

title: A fundamental way newspaper sites need to change
author: Adrian Holovaty
description: A hallmark essay on how data can be used in the very core of journalsitic operations, by the journalist who created the popular Django framework. Too bad his advice hasn't been heeded.

title: Serious Fun With Numbers
author: Janet Paskin
description: Daniel Gilbert had spreadsheets with thousands of rows of data. "There was a story there, he was certain. But control-f would not find it." After he took a class on how to use Microsoft Access, he could finally ask and answer the questions he knew were in the data. Gilbert's meticulously detailed series on landowners being cheated by oil and gas companies ended up winning a Pulitzer.

title: My Favorite (Excel) Things
author: MaryJo Webster
description: A short readable guide to one of the most vital and fundamental data journalism tools.

title: Design Principles for News Apps & Graphics
author: Lena Groeger
description: A well-lillustrated list of design concepts to bring to visualizations and news interactives.

title: Visual Literacy in an Age of Data
author: Shazna Nessa
description: Are modern web interactives becoming too complicate for users to interpret? Probably.

title: PowerPoint does Rocket Science - and Better Techniques for Technical Reports
author: Edward Tufte
description: How ugly formatting, including improperly bolded text, can obscure the important information in technical presentations.

title: Pie Charts
author: Edward Tufte discussion board
description: A great discussion between Edward Tufte and his readers on why pie charts aren't ideal.

title: Does High Public Debt Consistently Stifle Economic Growth? A Critique of Reinhart and Rogoff
author: Thomas Herndon, Michael Ash, and Robert Pollin
description: An influential economic analysis by two Harvard economists, based on a spreadsheet snafu? This paper and the articles that followed are a bag of laughs.

title: Common Static Visualization Types
author: Angela Zoss
description: Chart types, from simple to exotic, in tabular form.

title: Using Google Refine to Clean Messy Data
author: Daniel Nguyen
description: Google Refine is now Open Refine and its interface and feature sets have improved quite a bit since I wrote this essay. But it's still a good overview of how a single digital tool can make a data-intensive investigation possible.

title: Using Small Multiples to get to ‘Aha!
author: Matt Linderman
description: Applying Tufte's principle of small multiples to online video thumbnails.

title: Beautiful spider loses its way
author: Kaiser Fung
description: Charts can be too beautiful for their own good.

title: If correlation doesn’t imply causation, then what does?
author: Michael Nielsen
description: Predictably, the answer is very complicated and involves calculus.

title: Know Your Stats
author: Dave Stanton
description: A short list of statistical snafus as applied to data journalism.

title: The Perils of Polling Twitter
author: Jacob Harris
description: A nice explanation of selection bias, in the context of Twitter and other social media.

title: How the Data Sausage Gets Made
author: Jacob Harris
description: The horror of scraping government data.

title: Freeing the Plum Book
author: Derek Willis
description: A brilliant example of a (legal) hack to get public data.

title: Sane Data Updates are Harder Than You Think
author: Adrian Holovaty
description: A three-part series to just how complicated just doing data updates can be.

title: Culture Hacking with a Staff Database
author: Ian Malpass
description: Etsy found interesting and practical ways to mash up the (non-HR-private) data of its staff.

title: For Example
author: Mike Bostock
description: An awe-inspiring visual essay from the creator of D3, its purpose "to share my love of examples with you."

title: The different sketch styles of the designers at 37signals
author: Jason Fried
description: Drawn sketches can hint at what's visually compelling to the designer.

title: Why we skip Photoshop
author: Jason Fried
description: This is not really about data, but about the details of the creation process, and the importance of streamlining your workflow.

title: Common MySQL Queries
author: Peter Brawley and Arthur Fuller
description: If you're new to SQL, or even if you're skilled at it, this is one of the best collections of virtually every half-way complicated query you can dream of.

title: Machine Learning in R: Clustering
author: Ricky Ho

title: Getting your heart rate using R and Ruby
author: Sau Sheong Chang
description: A clever example of how to use code and available technology to track variables in the "meatspace"

title: Story hunting in birth, death data
author: Anthony DeBarros

title: Word clouds considered harmful
author: Jacob Harris
description: Another popular web visualization that is more junk than data.

title: A Gentle Introduction to SQL using SQLite
author: Troy Thibodeaux

title: I had no idea how to make custom maps, so I learnt by doing. You should too.
author: Alastair Coote
description: When you want something done beautifully, sometimes you have to do it yourself.

title: Console productivity hack: Discover the frequent; then make it the easy
author: Matt Might

title: Finding Stories in the Structure of Data
author: Matt Waite
description: How the structure of data can create new kinds of storytelling.

title: Data Mining: Finding Similar Items and Users
author: Alexandru Nedelcu

title: Data Mining the Web: $100 Worth of Priceless
description: A high-level description of the engineering used to mine and index 3.4 billion web pages in about 14 hours.

title: A Programmer's Guide to Data Mining
author: Ron Zacharski
description: A guide to practical data mining, collective intelligence, and building recommendation systems

title: Think Stats
author: Allen B. Downey
description: An introduction to Probability and Statistics for Python programmers.

title: Think Bayes
author: Allen B. Downey
description: An exploration of Bayesian statistics, using the Python programming language

title: Predictive Analytics: Data Preparation
author: Ricky Ho

title: Big Data Tutorials
author: Neal Caren

title: Bastards Book of Regular Expressions
author: Daniel Nguyen
description: If there's one data-related skill I wish I had learned years ago, it would be regular expressions.

title: Data Analysis for Politics and Policy
author: Edward Tufte

title: Up and Down the Ladder of Abstraction
author: Bret Victor

title: Scientific Communication as Sequential Art
author: Bret Victor

title: How to Design an Infographic: How Many Households
author: Bret Victor
description: A critique of a well-liked New York Times interactive.

title: Attempts to Map Music
author: Daniel Brownstein

title: Mapping NYC stop and frisks: some cartographic observations
author: Steven Romalewski
description: A critique of map design and thresholds, in the contest of the NYPD's stop-and-frisk data

title: How 2 Blade staffers overcame obstacles to cover Toledo’s gangs
author: Taylor Dungjen

title: Design Tip: Never Use Black
author: Ian Storm Taylor

title: The Greatest Paper Map of the United States You’ll Ever See
author: Seth Stevenson
description: A case for where hand-editing has advantages over algorithmic rendering.

title: Visualizing Slavery
author: Susan Schulten

title: People Power Prevails!
author: John Keefe

title: Cicada Tracker
author: WNYC and Radiolab
description: Easily one of the most esoteric and brilliant crowdsourcing data projects yet conceived.

title: GIS Analyses of Dr. Snow's Map
author: John Mackenzie

title: Mapping Chicago’s shooting victims
author: Andy Boyle

title: Proto-analysis of Boston Globe Traffic on Facebook
author: Sonya Song

title: Under the Hood of the Open Gender Tracker
author: Irene Ros and Nathan Matias

title: Creating a Metric for News Apps
author: Brian Abelson
description: A great explainer of how to implement real metrics to the field of news applications.

title: Matching Methods for Causal Inference
author: Elizabeth A. Stuart

title: Style and Substance: Analyzing a Beach Ball Chart
author: Joe Germuska
description: The beach ball chart is about as dumb as it sounds.

title: Better web cartography with dot density maps and new tools
author: Christopher Groskopf

title: How Not to Lie with Statistics: Avoiding Common Mistakes in Quantitative Political Science
author: Gary King

title: How we identified America's 50 worst charities
author: Kendall Taggart and Kris Hundley
description: How exactly do you define "worst"? Here's a high-level description of the factors reporters used to rank the performance of charity, and the amount of data they had to sift and analyze to do so.

title: Example story memos and assessments for class on "Real-Time Data; Using APIs"
author: Derek Willis

title: Analyzing the Analyzers: An Introspective Survey of Data Scientists and Their Work
author: Harlan Harris, Sean Murphy, Marck Vaisman

title: Drawing Conclusions from Data
author: Jonathan Stray

title: Making the WNYC Census Map
author: John Keefe

title: Months after West blast, a report highlights what we don’t know about chemical safety
author: Richard Parker

title: Principles of Information Display for Visualization Practitioners
author: Al Globus

title: Small Multiples with Details on Demand
author: Jim Vallandingham

title: The Rhetoric of Data
author: Nicholas Diakopoulos

title: Mapping Millions of Dots
author: Eric Fischer
description: Millions and millions of beautiful dots, without crashing your computer

title: Visualizing Data Uncertainty: An Experiment with D3.js
author: Alex Krusz

title: Hexbins!
author: Zachary Forest Johnson

title: Election 2012: Electoral combinations
author: Christopher Groskopf

title: The NYT's Visual Election Outcome Explorer
author: Mike Bostock
description: An behind-the-scenes explanation of how one of the best web visualizations ever was built.

title: Journalism in the Age of Data
author: Geoff McGhee
description: A video report on data visualization as a storytelling medium

title: Good Ol' Excel Is The Ultimate Data Visualization Tool (In Most Cases)
author: Cyrille Vincey
description: A nice guide on to turn stock Excel charts into something Tufte-approved.

title: Slopegraph theory and practice
author: Edward Tufte
